item.title: Israel Says It Destroyed Syria’s Navy, Part of Wave of Post-Assad Attacks
item.description: Israel says it is striking Syrian military sites to keep them out of “the hands of extremists.” The rebels who toppled the Assad government began laying out their plans while rival groups fought fierce battles for territory.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: How the Rebels in Syria Captured Damascus
item.description: A visual timeline of the stunning rebel advance in Syria
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Netanyahu Finally Takes the Stand in His Corruption Trial
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is accused of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in a trial that began four years ago. He has denied the charges.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu prepares to testify in his trial on corruption charges at the district court in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: In France, Marine Le Pen Takes Aim at the Top
item.description: After helping to oust the prime minister last week, the far-right leader has made clear her next target is President Emmanuel Macron.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: The far-right leader Marine Le Pen with President Emmanuel Macron after talks at the Élyseé Palace in Paris in 2022.

item.title: In Georgia Protests, Echoes of Ukraine’s Past Revolutions
item.description: This former Soviet Republic has been rocked by anti-government demonstrations over the same issues that hurtled Ukraine into war — its relationship with Europe and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Daro Sulakauri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fireworks set off by protesters exploded around riot police during a demonstration in Tbilisi, Georgia, last week.

item.title: A Tour of Assad’s Monumental Palace, With a Scruffy Rebel as a Guide
item.description: The televisions may be stripped away now, but a presidential residence still contains many remnants of a brutal reign.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Nicole Tung
item.media:description: Abu Oweis, a rebel fighter, in the office of a longtime senior adviser to Bashar al-Assad at the abandoned presidential palace in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Arrests Made in 2021 Crash That Killed Over 50 Migrants
item.description: U.S. and Guatemalan authorities said the arrests were linked to a human trafficking ring and a deadly 2021 traffic accident.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Josefa Quino Canil De Zavala after being detained on Monday in a joint operation between Guatemalan and U.S. authorities for alleged involvement in a deadly 2021 truck accident that killed more than 50 migrants in southern Mexico.

item.title: With Quick Vote and Little Fanfare, Saudi Arabia on Track to Get the 2034 World Cup
item.description: Critics have objected to the bidding process, and human rights groups have raised concerns about workplace safety for the migrants who will build the stadiums needed to host the event.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Argentina players celebrating with the trophy after winning the World Cup in December 2022, in Qatar.

item.title: Sednaya Prison in Syria: What to Know
item.description: Amnesty International described it as a “human slaughterhouse,” where, other rights groups say, tens of thousands of people were detained, tortured and killed during the 13-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:description: A man praying inside a liberated cell in Sednaya prison, in the suburbs of Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: South Korea’s Opposition Leader Determined to Oust President Yoon After Martial Law
item.description: Lee Jae-myung, the main opposition leader, is leading efforts to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his declaration of martial law. He could also be the next president.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, the leader of the opposition party, at his Democratic Party’s meeting room in the National Assembly in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: Lula, Brazil’s President, Is in ICU After Emergency Brain Surgery
item.description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil was in the hospital following the procedure. Doctors said the bleeding appeared to be linked to a fall in October.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil is recovering from an “uneventful” emergency surgery, according to the hospital that treated him.

item.title: Protests in Kenya Demand Action Over a Spate of Brutal Murders of Women
item.description: Almost 100 women have been killed in the span of three months, the police say. Rights groups want President William Ruto to declare femicide a national crisis.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Nairobi, Kenya, on Tuesday to demand that the government take action to stop the killings of women and girls.

item.title: Trump Mocks Trudeau and Canada in Post on Tariffs and Trade
item.description: The president-elect’s mockery of Canada and its leader is the latest salvo after his promise to impose steep tariffs on Canadian exports.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald Trump listening during a meeting in 2019 with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada.

item.title: Taiwan Says China Has Deployed Largest Fleet of Ships in Decades
item.description: Taiwan is on high alert in response to China’s unannounced deployment of naval and Coast Guard ships, as tensions rise over U.S. support for the island.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: A Taiwanese fighter jet landing in Hsinchu on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Offers Confusing Clues on Syria
item.description: The president-elect faces hard choices about the country’s post-Assad future. His vows not to get involved might be hard to keep.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Umayyad Square in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday, two days after President Bashar al-Assad fled the country and rebel forces took control of the capital.

item.title: A Northern Gaza Hospital Lacks Food and Water for Patients, Officials Say
item.description: The health ministry in Gaza said dozens of patients are at risk of death because the Indonesian Hospital does not have enough water and food to keep them alive.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: The Indonesian Hospital in the northern Gaza Strip after Israeli troops raided it in November 2023.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Vow Punishment for Atrocities Under Bashar al-Assad
item.description: The rebels who seized Damascus are trying to get a new government up and running, even as foreign powers like Israel and Turkey, and armed Syrian groups, fight for power.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad, Qasim Nauman and Thomas Fuller
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A defaced portrait of the ousted Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, beside a highway in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: French Court Finds Author Charles Onana Guilty of Denying Rwandan Genocide
item.description: Charles Onana and his publisher were fined for passages in a book that were found to have violated a French law making it illegal to deny an officially recognized genocide.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Family photographs of some of those who died in the Rwandan genocide on display in the Kigali Genocide Memorial Center in Kigali, Rwanda, in 2014.

item.title: Uncertainty and Hope on the Road to and from Damascus
item.description: Thousands of Syrians have been traveling to and from the Lebanese border since the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Some families hoped to reunite with loved ones, while others are leaving amid an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel, Alessandro Pavone and Mark Boyer
item.media:credit: Alessandro Pavone for The New York Times

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Wave of Post-Assad Attacks
item.description: Plus, how Netflix brought a magical town to life.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle entering the buffer zone with Syria.

item.title: Cyclist Rohan Dennis Pleads Guilty in Death of Wife Melissa Hoskins, Fellow Olympian
item.description: Rohan Dennis pleaded guilty this week to a lesser charge in the death of Melissa Hoskins last year, after he drove with her on the hood of a vehicle, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Rohan Dennis pleaded guilty to creating a risk of harm. He faces seven years in prison.

item.title: Monarch Butterflies Are Recommended for Protected Status in U.S.
item.description: They would become the most commonly seen species to receive federal protection if the proposal is adopted.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Nic Coury for The New York Times

item.title: Arctic Tundra Has Long Helped Cool Earth. Now, It’s Fueling Warming.
item.description: Wildfires and thawing permafrost are causing the region to release more carbon dioxide than its plants remove, probably for the first time in thousands of years.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hill with an ice core, known as a pingo, in the Mackenzie River Delta, Northwest Territories.

item.title: Police Arrest 3 After Deadly Explosion in the Netherlands
item.description: The blast, which the mayor of The Hague called an “unprecedented disaster,” killed six people on Saturday morning.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: An explosion and fire killed at least six people and destroyed part of an apartment building in The Hague, the Netherlands, on Saturday.

item.title: Israel Strikes Military Assets Across Syria to Keep Them From Rebels
item.description: Israel capitalized on the power vacuum in Syria to bomb targets across the country, saying it aims to keep weapons away from extremists.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath on Tuesday of an overnight strike on the Barzah scientific research center, which had been linked to the Syrian government’s chemical weapons program.

item.title: South Korea Martial Law Fallout: What to Know on Yoon’s Future
item.description: The president faces an accusation of insurrection and, in a first for a sitting leader, the possibility of arrest. Here’s what to know about his political future.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers near the National Assembly in Seoul last week after President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law.

item.title: On the Ground in Damascus as Syrians Chart a New Path
item.description: In a matter of days, Syria’s capital — once the stronghold of Bashar al-Assad’s government — became the epicenter of a new chapter in the country’s history after opposition forces overran the city. Christina Goldbaum, a New York Times correspondent, traveled to Damascus to find out how residents were reacting to the sudden breakthrough in the 13-year civil war as more than five decades of brutal rule by the Assad dynasty come to an end.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Nikolay Nikolov, Christina Shaman and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: Prince William and Jacob Elordi Grow Beards That Spark Strong Feelings
item.description: Whether on Prince William, JD Vance or Jacob Elordi, facial hair gets people talking.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince William has had a beard at multiple public appearances in recent weeks.

item.title: Here’s How Much Cleaner Energy Could Save America, in Lives and Money
item.description: Widespread adoption of heat pumps could prevent thousands of premature deaths and save billions on energy bills, according to a new analysis.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times

item.title: Australia Signs Security and Economic Treaty With Nauru
item.description: In return for financial support, the Pacific island nation of Nauru pledged not to enter any security pacts without Australia’s assent.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Dominic Giannini/AAP Image, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia and President David Adeang of Nauru meeting in Canberra, Australia, on Monday.

item.title: Volcanic Eruption in the Philippines Forces Mass Evacuation
item.description: Nearly 90,000 people on the island of Negros were ordered to seek shelter after Mount Kanlaon spewed deadly ash and lava.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology via Associated Press

item.title: How to Understand the Armed Factions Operating in Syria
item.description: The fighters shared a desire to topple Bashar al-Assad’s government, but they don’t share much else.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Celebrations at Umayyad Square in Damascus on Monday.

item.title: What to Know About the Countries Still Fighting in Syria After al-Assad’s Ouster
item.description: Bashar al-Assad is gone, and Russia and Iran have stepped back. But Israel, Turkey and the United States are carrying out airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria hanging on the side of a shopping mall decimated by bombs in the war-ravaged city of Homs, Syria, in June.

item.title: The Netanyahu Corruption Trial, Explained
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took the stand on Tuesday. Here’s what to know about the trial.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addressing lawmakers in the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament, in Jerusalem, in November.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Syrians celebrated in Umayyad Square in Damascus yesterday.

item.title: Syrians, in Shock and With Some Unease, Celebrate the Fall of al-Assad
item.description: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Thousands of Syrians celebrated in the streets of Umayyad Square in the center of Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Syrian Military Officials Charged With War Crimes as Government Falls
item.description: The officials, Jamil Hassan and Abdul Salam Mahmoud, ran an infamous prison in Damascus and “sought to terrify, intimidate and repress any opposition, or perceived opposition, to the regime,” according to the indictment.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The Mezzeh air base in Damascus, Syria, where two officials were accused of committing war crimes and running a notorious prison facility.

item.title: U.S. Scrambles to Navigate Perils of a New Syria
item.description: The Biden administration is relying on Turkey to convey messages to Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which toppled Bashar al-Assad but is designated by the U.S. as a terrorist organization.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. officials say they are closely watching to see whether Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, led by Abu Mohammed al-Jolani, displays traits of a terrorist group or whether it has changed.

item.title: Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire Talks Gain Steam, Officials Say
item.description: While a deal was not yet in hand, a crack in the stalemate comes after Israel and Hezbollah reached a truce and President-elect Donald J. Trump ratcheted up the pressure for an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: A makeshift camp for displaced Palestinians in the Nahr al-Bared area in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Syrian Rebels Rush to Establish Order
item.description: Plus, a lawsuit for trans rights in China.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Celebrations in Umayyad Square in Damascus yesterday.

item.title: Syria’s President Had Stocks of Chemical Weapons. What Happens to Them Now?
item.description: While experts believe that Syria has retained some stocks of chemical weapons, their quantities likely have been depleted and it would be hard for rogue actors to use them.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.media:description: A Syrian rebel tries on a gas mask seized from a Syrian army factory in the northwestern province of Idlib in 2013. Bashar al-Assad’s use of chemical weapons on rebels and civilians was a defining feature of the early days of Syria’s civil war.

item.title: A Quick Arab Pivot: From Welcoming al-Assad to Managing the Chaos
item.description: Only weeks ago, Arab nations had been working hard to bring Bashar al-Assad back into the fold, assuming he was there to last. They were badly mistaken.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Chatham House (The Royal Institute of International Affairs)
item.media:description: A torn poster of the deposed Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad at an abandoned border checkpoint in Masnaa, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Crowds Throng to Syria’s Sednaya Prison to Find Relatives and Friends
item.description: The Assad regime ran a network of torture centers that swallowed up tens of thousands of Syrians. Now that the rebels have opened the gates, many see a chance to learn of the detainees’ fates.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Surveying cells in the Sednaya Prison on Monday in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Explosion at Fuel Depot Near Florence Kills at Least Two
item.description: Officials said it would take time to determine the cause of the explosion. At least 26 people were injured in the blast.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Smoke billowed from the depot near Florence, Italy, after the explosion on Monday.

item.title: How Syria’s Rebels Took Damascus, Captured on Video
item.description: Bashar Al-Assad’s grip over Syria was visible everywhere in the capital. It was all dismantled in less than 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrians celebrating in the central city of Homs early on Sunday.

item.title: Displaced Syrians Rush to Return Home
item.description: The 13-year conflict in Syria caused one of the “largest displacement crises in the world,” according to the United Nations. Now, an untold number of people are trying to go back.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: People traveling on the road to Damascus, the Syrian capital, from Beirut, Lebanon, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Claims Credit for al-Assad’s Ouster, but Sees Risk in His Absence
item.description: For Israel’s leaders, Bashar al-Assad’s downfall was made possible by their recent assaults on Hezbollah, Iran and Syria, all of which weakened the Iran-backed axis.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Celebrating the fall of Bashar al-Assad on a road leading to Syria’s Masnaa border crossing in Bar Elias, Lebanon, on Sunday.

item.title: E.P.A. Bans Perc and T.C.E., Two Chemicals Used In Dry Cleaning
item.description: The two solvents, known as Perc and TCE, cause kidney cancer and other ailments, and have been the subject of years of controversy.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The dry-cleaning industry has objected to new restrictions imposed by the Environmental Protection Agency.

item.title: Desperate Haitians Who Fled to the Dominican Republic Are Being Sent Back in Cages
item.description: Relations between the neighboring countries on the island of Hispaniola have long been frosty. They are now complicated by up to 10,000 deportations a week.
item.dc:creator: Hogla Enecia Pérez and Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Haitians detained for deportation in a police vehicle between the Dominican Republic and Haiti.

item.title: Ukraine Weighs Telegram Security Risks Amid War With Russia
item.description: The messaging app’s popularity has soared during the war with Russia, leading Ukrainian officials to increasingly weigh Telegram’s upsides against its security risks.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Telegram’s Air Raids Map channel. Roughly 70 percent of Ukrainians use Telegram as a main source of news, according to a recent survey.

item.title: Road to Damascus Littered With Relics of Fallen Assad Government
item.description: Reporters for The New York Times entered Syria on Monday, finding remnants of former President Bashar al-Assad’s oppressive rule.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak and Christina Goldbaum/The New York Times

item.title: Three-Quarters of Earth’s Land Got Drier in Recent Decades, U.N. Says
item.description: Human-caused global warming helped increase dry conditions on every continent, scientists said in a new report, as talks on halting desertification were underway in Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A goat farmer in a drought-stricken area of Leonforte, Sicily, in July.

item.title: South Korea Bars President From Traveling Abroad
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol cannot leave the country as an investigation unfolds into whether he led an insurrection last week when he briefly imposed martial law.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea with Oh Dong-woon in May, when Mr. Oh was appointed as head of the office investigating high-ranking officials.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A historic transition of power in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A toppled statue of Syria’s late president, Hafez al-Assad, in Damascus yesterday.

item.title: Revolutions Swept the Middle East in 2011. Will Syria’s End Differently?
item.description: Bashar al-Assad’s downfall evokes memories of uprisings in Egypt, Libya, Tunisia and Yemen, each of which brought civil war or authoritarian rule. Syrians hope for better.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Hundreds celebrated the end of Bashar al-Assad’s long and brutal grip on Syria on Sunday on a road leading to the border between Lebanon and Syria.

item.title: Massacre in Haiti Ordered by Gang Leader Leaves Over 100 Dead, Rights Group Says
item.description: The killings in a Port-au-Prince slum, which appeared to target practitioners of Voodoo, were ordered by a gang leader, a Haitian human rights organization said.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: An armored police vehicle in Cité Soleil, a slum in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, in May.

item.title: Trump Picks Former Ambassador to Mexico for Deputy Secretary of State
item.description: Christopher Landau is a longtime lawyer and the son of a veteran U.S. diplomat who served as ambassador to three nations in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Christopher Landau in 2019. Because of his background in dealing with Mexico, Mr. Landau could be tasked with handling migration and tariffs in the Trump administration.

item.title: With Syria in Flux, Turkish Forces Attack U.S.-Backed Forces
item.description: Rebels supported by Turkish air power fired on a Kurdish-controlled city in northern Syria, pitting proxies of the U.S. and Turkey — NATO allies — against each other.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Destroying a statue of Bassel al-Assad, the ousted president’s brother, on Sunday in Qamishli, Syria, on the border with Turkey.

item.title: Stunned Iranian Officials Try to Distance Their Country From Assad
item.description: A reckoning emerged in Iran on Sunday as officials and commentators swiftly moved to distance the government from a tyrant it had supported.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The damage after Syrians looted the Iranian Embassy in Damascus, Syria’s capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Syrians in New York City Celebrate the Fall of Assad
item.description: Syrian expatriates and their supporters beat drums and sang revolutionary songs in Arabic at a gathering in Washington Square Park.
item.dc:creator: Sabir Hasko
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcelle Shehwaro, center, a Syrian activist, celebrated the fall of the Assad regime along with other activists and supporters in Washington Square Park on Sunday.
